definition: to catch sight of in a doorway (old)
board/plank/plate/shutter/table tennis bat/clappers (music)/CL:塊|块[kuai4]/accented beat in Chinese music/hard/stiff/to stop smiling or look serious

sentences.english: I can rebound and I can score occasionally.
sentences.chinese: 我偶尔能够抢到篮板球或投篮得分。

sentences.english: I think Josh is probably a better perimeter shooter and rebounder than Ronny.
sentences.chinese: 我认为约什在投篮和抢篮板球能力上比罗尼更好些。

sentences.english: And why is Juwon always trying to snatch the rebound away from his teammates?
sentences.chinese: 为什么霍华德总是从他得队友那里挣篮板球呢？

sentences.english: Pau and Andrew, their work on the boards tonight was sensational.
sentences.chinese: 加索尔和拜纳姆在保护篮板球上是很出色的。

sentences.english: He was elbowed in the face, trying to get the rebound.
sentences.chinese: 在抢篮板球时，他被胳膊肘撞到了脸。

sentences.english: I caught a rebound and made a basket.
sentences.chinese: 我抢到一个篮板球，投进了一个球。

sentences.english: He set up teammates, grabbed rebounds and made the game his.
sentences.chinese: 他助攻队友，抓篮板球而且使整个比赛成为他的。

sentences.english: He rebounded the ball in backcourt.
The crowd watched intently as the ball player score rebound.
sentences.chinese: 观众们聚精会神地看着这个球员抢下篮板球。

sentences.english: And my rebounds are also not bad.
Gasol led the Lakers with 21 points and 11 rebounds.
sentences.chinese: 加索尔带领湖人比赛，拿下21分11个篮板球。

definition: (military) line of troops encircling an enemy position/(telephony) outside line/(basketball) outside the three-point line
to hit the target with one's throw/(basketball) to score
to fight desperately (at the risk of one's life)
half of a game or contest/half-court
